question: What is this {medium} for?
answer: This {medium} invites you to join with Christians around the world in praying with the Church, at any time or in any place you may find yourself. It makes it easy to pray daily morning, midday, evening, and compline (bedtime) prayer without flipping pages, searching for scripture readings or calendars, or interpreting rubrics. The prayers are presented from The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America and reflect the ancient patterns of daily prayer Christians have used since the earliest days of the church.
answer_for_web: This site invites you to join with Christians around the world in praying with the Church, at any time or in any place you may find yourself. It makes it easy to pray daily morning, midday, evening, and compline (bedtime) prayer without flipping pages, searching for scripture readings or calendars, or interpreting rubrics. The prayers are presented from The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America and reflect the ancient patterns of daily prayer Christians have used since the earliest days of the church.

It makes it easy to pray daily morning, midday, evening, and compline (bedtime) prayer without flipping pages, searching for scripture readings or calendars, or interpreting rubrics. The prayers are presented from The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America and reflect the ancient patterns of daily prayer Christians have used since the earliest days of the church.

question: What is the Daily Office?
answer:
Daily Morning Prayer and Daily Evening Prayer are the established rites (offices) by which, both corporately and individually, God’s people annually encounter the whole of the Holy Scriptures, daily confess their sins and praise Almighty God, and offer timely thanksgivings, petitions, and intercessions.

From the Book of Common Prayer (2019)
answer_for_web:
Daily Morning Prayer and Daily Evening Prayer are the established rites (offices) by which, both corporately and individually, God’s people annually encounter the whole of the Holy Scriptures, daily confess their sins and praise Almighty God, and offer timely thanksgivings, petitions, and intercessions.

From the Book of Common Prayer (2019)

From the Book of Common Prayer (2019)

question: Where are the prayers taken from?
question_for_web: Where are the prayers taken from?
question_for_app: Where are the prayers taken from?
answer: These prayers are excellent for use by Christians of any tradition, but this site is intended to accurately reflect the liturgy, calendar, and rubrics of The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America. The official texts can be found on the website of the Anglican Church in North America.
answer_for_web: These prayers are excellent for use by Christians of any tradition, but this site is intended to accurately reflect the liturgy, calendar, and rubrics of The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America. The official texts can be found on the website of the Anglican Church in North America.

The official texts can be found on the website of the Anglican Church in North America.

question: Is this {medium} a complete substitute for the paper Book of Common Prayer?
question_for_web: Is this site a complete substitute for the paper Book of Common Prayer?
question_for_app: Is this app a complete substitute for the paper Book of Common Prayer?
answer:
No. While the {medium} is a great and easy way to pray the Daily Offices of Morning, Midday, Evening, and Bedtime Prayer, there are many other excellent prayers and resources in the printed book.

For personal devotions at home, some may like to use this {medium} exclusively. Others, however, will prefer the meditative (and push notification-free) quality of reading from the physical book. This {medium} can still be a great backup for occasions, such as traveling or at work, when you find yourself without a book.

You can buy the 2019 Book of Common Prayer directly from Anglican House Publishers, which graciously sponsors this site.
answer_for_web:
No. While the site is a great and easy way to pray the Daily Offices of Morning, Midday, Evening, and Bedtime Prayer, there are many other excellent prayers and resources in the printed book.

For personal devotions at home, some may like to use this site exclusively. Others, however, will prefer the meditative (and push notification-free) quality of reading from the physical book. This site can still be a great backup for occasions, such as traveling or at work, when you find yourself without a book.

You can buy the 2019 Book of Common Prayer directly from Anglican House Publishers, which graciously sponsors this site.

This app can still be a great backup for occasions, such as traveling or at work, when you find yourself without a book.

question: Which translation of the Bible is used?
question_for_web: Which translation of the Bible is used?
question_for_app: Which translation of the Bible is used?
answer:
By default, scripture readings are taken from the English Standard Version. Readings from the Deuterocanon/Apocrypha are taken from the New Revised Standard Version. The Psalter is the New Coverdale Psalter from The Book of Common Prayer (2019) or the Coverdale Psalter from the Traditional Language Edtion of The Book of Common Prayer (2019). Additional translations available under settings include the King James Versions/Authorized Edition, The Revised Standard Edition, the New American Standard Bible, the New International Version, and the New American Bible: Revised Edition.

Scripture quotations are from the ESV® Bible (The Holy Bible, English Standard Version®), copyright © 2001 by Crossway Bibles, a publishing ministry of Good News Publishers. Used by permission. All rights reserved. | New Revised Standard Version Bible: Catholic Edition, copyright © 1989, 1993 National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America. Used by permission. All rights reserved worldwide.

question: Is there a shorter version?
answer: Yes, try out the Family Prayer version, which follows the same basic pattern but is much shorter.  It has its own dedicated settings.
answer_for_web: Yes, try out the Family Prayer version, which follows the same basic pattern but is much shorter.  It has its own dedicated settings.
answer_for_app: Yes, try out the Family Prayer version, which follows the same basic pattern but is much shorter.  It has its own dedicated settings.

question: Can I customize the prayers to the way I usually pray the Daily Office?
question_for_web: Can I customize the prayers to the way I usually pray the Daily Office?
question_for_app: Can I customize the prayers to the way I usually pray the Daily Office?
answer: Yes! We’ve chosen good default options so you can start praying right away. If you prefer different options, we offer many choices under "Settings". Currently, it is possible to change from a one-year to a two-year cycle of scripture readings, switch from a sixty-day cycle to a thirty-day cycle of psalms, and make other choices as permitted in the rubrics of The Book of Common Prayer (2019). Your settings will be saved the next time you pray on the same computer/phone/device and browser.
answer_for_web: Yes! We’ve chosen good default options so you can start praying right away. If you prefer different options, we offer many choices under "Settings". Currently, it is possible to change from a one-year to a two-year cycle of scripture readings, switch from a sixty-day cycle to a thirty-day cycle of psalms, and make other choices as permitted in the rubrics of The Book of Common Prayer (2019). Your settings will be saved the next time you pray on the same computer/phone/device and browser.

question: Is this an official project?
answer: This site and app were built as a personal project and remain independent. They intend, as much as possible, to accurately reflect The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America. It is now financially supported by Anglican House Publishers, which prints the prayerbook.
answer_for_web: This site and app were built as a personal project and remain independent. They intend, as much as possible, to accurately reflect The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America. It is now financially supported by Anglican House Publishers, which prints the prayerbook.
answer_for_app: This site and app were built as a personal project and remain independent. They intend, as much as possible, to accurately reflect The Book of Common Prayer (2019) of the Anglican Church in North America. It is now financially supported by Anglican House Publishers, which prints the prayerbook.

question: Why should I use this {medium} instead of the others also available?
question_for_web: Why should I use this site instead of the others also available?
question_for_app: Why should I use this app instead of the others also available?
answer: This site and app are built to be streamlined, clean, and easy-to-use while being extremely flexible for those who want a greater level of control over how they pray. They are also very accurate and faithful to the text, rubrics, and calendar of The Book of Common Prayer (2019). All that said, please use what works for you. Legereme / BCP 2019 or Church of the Incarnation, Bryan/College Station are other great options for the 2019 prayer book texts. Venite.app, St. Bede's Breviary, Mission St. Clare, and dailyoffice.app are great options for the 1979 prayer book texts.

question: How can I use this {medium} to pray in a group or remotely?
question_for_web: How can I use this site to pray in a group or remotely?
question_for_app: How can I use this app to pray in a group or remotely?
answer:
After you set up your preferred settings, click the "Share Settings" link at the top of the page. Copy the provided link, and share it via email, text message, Facebook, or your website.  This ensures everyone will be praying with the same settings.

Many churches have also chosen to display dailyoffice2019.com with the "Share screen" or "Presentation" mode of Zoom, Google Meet, Facebok Live, or other live streaming or pre-recorded platforms, so those who are watching can follow along.

Many churches have also chosen to display dailyoffice2019.com with the "Share screen" or "Presentation" mode of Zoom, Google Meet, Facebok Live, or other live streaming or pre-recorded platforms, so those who are watching can follow along.

question: Where can I provide feedback?
answer: Send an email to feedback@dailyoffice2019.com or post in our Facebook group. We welcome suggestions for new features or ways to make this site easier to use. We especially appreciate corrections for errors in the text, calendar, or rubrics.

question: How much of scripture is read?
question_for_web: How much of scripture is read?
question_for_app: How much of scripture is read?
answer:
The Old Testament is read in its entirety once each year (with the exception of a few passages in Leviticus, Numbers, Joshua, Judges, Ezra, Nehemiah, Ezekiel, and the majority of Chronicles). The Gospels and Acts are read in their entirety twice each year, at Morning Prayer during the first part of the year, at Evening Prayer during the second part of the year. The Epistles are read twice each year in the opposite pattern, except for the Revelation to John, which is read only once, during the Advent season. Select passages of the Apocrypha have been retained. In general, readings move continuously through books of the Bible, interrupted only by Holy Days. For most Holy Days a single proper lesson is included, usually in Morning Prayer. For major feasts of our Lord, two proper lessons are included.

Adapted from the Book of Common Prayer (2019)
answer_for_web:
The Old Testament is read in its entirety once each year (with the exception of a few passages in Leviticus, Numbers, Joshua, Judges, Ezra, Nehemiah, Ezekiel, and the majority of Chronicles). The Gospels and Acts are read in their entirety twice each year, at Morning Prayer during the first part of the year, at Evening Prayer during the second part of the year. The Epistles are read twice each year in the opposite pattern, except for the Revelation to John, which is read only once, during the Advent season. Select passages of the Apocrypha have been retained. In general, readings move continuously through books of the Bible, interrupted only by Holy Days. For most Holy Days a single proper lesson is included, usually in Morning Prayer. For major feasts of our Lord, two proper lessons are included.

Adapted from the Book of Common Prayer (2019)

question: Can I help build this site?
question_for_web: Can I help build this site?
question_for_app: Can I help build this site?
answer:
Yes!

If you are a coder, go to the GitHub repo, look at the issues list, and consider contributing to the code base. If you have an idea that isn't listed, just submit it as an issue and we can discuss.

If you aren't a coder, there are many other ways to help.  Get in touch at feedback@dailyoffice2019.com.

Yes!

If you are a coder, go to the GitHub repo, look at the issues list, and consider contributing to the code base. If you have an idea that isn't listed, just submit it as an issue and we can discuss.

If you aren't a coder, there are many other ways to help.  Get in touch at feedback@dailyoffice2019.com.

answer: The 2019 in the site's address reflects that this site uses prayers from the 2019 edition of the Book of Common Prayer.  It doesn't reflect the current year.

answer: Visit https://www.dailyoffice2019.com. It has almost all the same functionality as the app, except it isn't available offline.

question: Acknowledgments
answer:
This site was initially created by Benjamin Locher. Many others have contributed since then. Thanks especially to:

- Jacob Hootman, secretary for the Liturgy Task Force, for help compiling the Traditional Language Edition materials

- Fr. Joshua Steele at Anglican Compass for his spreadsheet of readings and ongoing advice and publicity

- Fr. Ben Jefferies for his design inspiration, advice, and coordination with Anglican House Publishers (the publisher of the prayerbook)

- liturgical-calendar.com for providing the Sunday and holy day lectionary

- Fr. Matthew Brench at St. Aelfric's Customary for his work on the canticle schedule and other parts of the site

- Anglican House Publishers for financial support

Thanks also to the many users who have provided feedback, suggestions, and bug reports via feedback@dailyoffice2019.com or the Facebook Group.

- Fr. Joshua Steele at Anglican Compass for his spreadsheet of readings and ongoing advice and publicity

- Fr. Ben Jefferies for his design inspiration, advice, and coordination with Anglican House Publishers (the publisher of the prayerbook)

- liturgical-calendar.com for providing the Sunday and holy day lectionary

- Fr. Matthew Brench at St. Aelfric's Customary for his work on the canticle schedule and other parts of the site

- Anglican House Publishers for financial support

Thanks also to the many users who have provided feedback, suggestions, and bug reports via feedback@dailyoffice2019.com or the Facebook Group.
